sub_topic: Coordination chemistry of metalloenzymes and metalloproteins
message_1: What is the coordination mode and geometry of the metal ion in the active site of the metalloenzyme carbonic anhydrase? Identify the definition and structure of the ligands involved in binding the metal ion, and explain the role of the metal ion in the catalytic mechanism of the protein.
message_2:
The metal ion in the active site of the metalloenzyme carbonic anhydrase is zinc (Zn²⁺). The coordination mode and geometry of the zinc ion is tetrahedral. In this geometry, the zinc ion is coordinated to three histidine residues (His94, His96, and His119 in human carbonic anhydrase II) and a water molecule or hydroxide ion.

The ligands involved in binding the metal ion are the imidazole rings of the histidine residues and the oxygen atom of the water molecule or hydroxide ion. The histidine residues are part of the protein's primary structure, and their side chains contain nitrogen atoms that can act as electron pair donors, forming coordinate covalent bonds with the zinc ion. The water molecule or hydroxide ion acts as a Lewis base, donating an electron pair to the zinc ion.

The role of the zinc ion in the catalytic mechanism of carbonic anhydrase is to facilitate the conversion of carbon dioxide (CO₂) and water (H₂O) into bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) and a proton (H⁺). The zinc ion activates the water molecule or hydroxide ion by polarizing the O-H bond, making it more nucleophilic. This activated species then attacks the carbon dioxide molecule, leading to the formation of bicarbonate. The zinc ion also helps stabilize the negatively charged transition state during the reaction, lowering the activation energy and increasing the reaction rate.

In summary, the metal ion in the active site of carbonic anhydrase is zinc, with a tetrahedral coordination geometry. The ligands involved in binding the metal ion are the imidazole rings of three histidine residues and a water molecule or hydroxide ion. The zinc ion plays a crucial role in the catalytic mechanism of the protein by activating the water molecule or hydroxide ion and stabilizing the transition state during the reaction.
